regretList.regret: Alcohol unlocked something in my introverted nature early in my 20s, allowing me to be more outgoing, leading me to believe that my experiences and self were bound to the substance forever. In actuality, I reached a crucial fulcrum in life and drinking contributed to a malaise and two years of inactivity when I could of moved on to the adventure I knew in my heart was waiting for me (joining a community called L'Arche, which led to meeting my wife, finding a new home in midwestern city I love, and finding a vocation in social work that brings me fulfillment in relationship that I couldn't find while I was drinking).

I regret that after I divorced, I chose another partner who had a temper and turned out to be horrible to my children. I regret that I stayed with him for so long thinking that I could "mediate" every conflict and keep everyone happy. My children suffered during a large portion of their childhood because of my choice and my conflict aversion.
I wish I had moved out of my my home town when I was younger.
I regret not having more confidence in myself when I was younger to make better decisions. I still love who I am today, but I wish I'd taken more risks when I was younger.
Relationships
Not going on that last spring break
Relationships
Not traveling independently at a young age when I had no responsibilities.

I wish I would have recognized that I was an alcoholic well before I ruined relationships...friendships, romantic relationships, family, business. I wish I would have figured out sooner...then I would not have cheated on my girlfriend and put mine and other's lives at risk since I drove drunk nearly every day for YEARS.
I regret having a five year affair on my husband. I wish I would have never hurt him so much.

In the 8th grade I robbed and trashed the home of a good friend with two other classmates. I don’t know how I came to do it. It wasn’t premeditated. Our friend wasn’t home and we just went inside and things got out of hand. The fall out was severe. Criminal action, shame, being bullied, loss of friendships, disappointment, fear. My self esteem completely evaporated. Thirty years later I think about it all the time. I daydream of going back in time to the day before. I think so many things about who I am would be different. But I also don’t know if that’s true. Maybe I never would have left home if I hadn’t felt like an outcast. I have gone on to be a good friend, neighbor, citizen. Nothing about how I acted that night relates to who went in to be in the years that followed or who I am today but it still crushes me and I can’t forgive myself. Or don’t know how.
Not divorcing my husband ten years ago

I sincerely regret the amount of time and energy I have spent trying to be likable, or to fit in. I spent so much time worrying about fitting in that I ended up becoming who others wanted, stayed in bad relationships way too long, and allowed people to stay in my life that didn't care about me. More than anything, my need to not make noise meant I didn't admit or tell anyone about the several rapes I experienced as a young adult by a family member, which resulted in several mental health breakdowns later in life. If I could talk to my 15-year-old self, I would tell her that she is EXACTLY who she is meant to be, that the people in life that are worth keeping are those that will see her value, and she must be her own advocate.
I regret staying in a relationship that wasn't fulfilling for too long./
I regret lashing out on people who hurt me. It was wrong some of the things they did. but I feel like I hurt people worse because of my anger and my inability to handle it.
That I allowed my parents way too much control over big decisions in my life--usually via guilt/shame.    Like giving up a horse I loved.
Becoming emotionally involved with my sister in law's husband.
Being an alcoholic from age 13-23. Not working harder in university.
RELATIONSHIPS
Never letting him know I loved him before he committed suicide
Staying in a relationship that is unhealthy
Quitting a job I really liked because I felt I was not being appreciated enough. My other job turn out to be worse.
I regret being a stay at home mom and not having a great career of my own.

I regret not listening to my gut when I first met the man who raped me. I saw right through him, but was so desperate for friends that I ignored everything telling me he was only going to cause trouble.
I wish I had told him that I wasn't going to marry him before he moved across the world

I misunderstood a situation and took the opportunity to talk ill about the son of a family friend that had recently passed, I thought it was fake news and part of a grand plan to assess my competence, reasoning, and decision making abilities. I was under the impression that the son was the mastermind and since everyone was playing I chose to get in the mud. Unfortunately, I was wrong and have had to deal with this regret every single day. I went as far as telling an accomplice that we had made It! It's way worse than it sounds and I accepted a lot of retaliation because of self-imposed punishment. I subsequently went on a tangent of feining craziness and attacking everyone I assessed was involved in the scheme. I regret this because I acted a tad beyond my character to try to control and understand an uncontrollable situation. It was fundamentally painful, as I had to live with the effects of my initial antics and the pain of the subsequent ones.
Doing much poorly in school than I should have. I believe it guided or limited my career.

I regret staying in a career for over a decade before thinking about what I really wanted from it, and also realizing the good things about it. I'm in a different job now in a different city and I look back on my previous one and think about how I didn't realize all of the good things that I had -- both in my job and in that previous location.  I wish I had spent more time reflecting on the positive and making space for things that mattered when I had a lot of freedom to do so.
Not reconnecting with a college boyfriend when I got back from my junior year abroad.
Did not go to graduate school after being accepted and after more than 10 years of wanting to go back to for an advanced degree.

I regret not buying out my brother to keep our family houses after my mother passed away. He sued me to force the sale and I did not buy out his share. It was a bad choice emotionally and financially and our family is now torn apart. The house that my mother wanted kept in the family was sold and torn down. I also gave my brother and sister large portions of my inheritance in order to try and stop it, but that only served to further enrich them.
Getting my masters degree and starting my career as a coach sooner.
I regret staying silent about the pain I was in during high school of my anxiety in the late 80s and 90s. I regret not being stronger against mean girls and sticking up for myself during that time.
I am sorry I didn't start dating a friend in college when he asked me out.
I regret being involved with a person who was not good for me and wasting 5 years of my life.
I did not exactly verbalize I wanted to break up with my first girlfriend. She was and assume is still a great soul. She did not deserve me just 'moving on' without telling her.

I regret not staying single and working through the loneliness and impatience I felt at the time. I might have had a better chance at meeting the love of my life or at least stayed true to myself had I waited. Instead, I settled for the person I married whom I believe settled for me too. I’m sad for us both.
I regret I didn't work harder at school during high school.

My most significant regret is not having the confidence or courage to continue my studies toward medical school. I think I quit (before I even got in to med school) because I did not really believe I could and was afraid to fail.
Not staying at a job that would have set me up for life.
I regret not making better career decisions after high school.
Not taking more chances with physically dangerous activities that are fun adventures that others did do

Being an introspective and philosophical person, I could look back on any part of my life and pick out a regret. So, it’s hard to pinpoint just one or the most prominent one. With that being stated, I think the regret that stands out the most is my sexual promiscuity when I was a teenager. I had sex with a girl and felt tremendous guilt afterward. I never talked to her again… That is no way to treat another human being, even when a mistake is made. I have used that mistake to make sure I am always compassionate to people no matter what situation precedes.
My biggest regret is missing out on living and never truly having any life in my 20s and 30s because I refused to challenge my negative beliefs and face my fears.
I regret using my body as a means of finding love and validation.
Doing things to please others just not to hurt their feelings, even if my own feelings were being shattered.
I regret not visiting elderly family members who would die before I saw them again.  I regret being not fully present in conversations with sick friends who would die before we talked again.

I regret not having being more accesible to connect with people who loved me, or even the ones, family, friends, co workers, etc who wanted to know me better, fearing intimacy and putting walls in between.
Spanish is my mom's first language, but we never spoke it at home growing up. I'm now 31 and have been trying to learn Spanish for the past 2 years. I regret not learning it when I was young.
I regret not answering the phone when my dad called, because he died a few days later, and I never returned his call.
I regret always pushing my dad away before he passed away.
I regret not taking classes at the community college while I was in high school.
Not having more children

One of the things that I significantly regret is not taking chances. I have a desire to move to my home country, but I feel stuck. I wish I was already there but I still have time, of course, but my life isn’t going as once planned. The thing is that I know that life won’t work out in the way that I want it to, but it would be nice, right?
I regret not having the third child I always wanted. It’s too late now.
I regret that I’ve allowed my fear of failure to paralyze me from taking risks personally and professionally.

My grandmother wasn't feeling well one day and she asked me to prepare something for dinner. I was really tired and told her I just didn't feel like doing it.  She died a couple months later and I always regretted not preparing that meal.

One significant regret I have is related to my career.  I left a comfortable job to take a much higher paying job with promotion.  Within 60 days, there were company changes and the new leadership took away my promotion but kept same pay.  I let my ego take the best of me, I resigned because the position offered was not in leadership, it was administrative. I loved that team.  So, I found a leadership position in a different company that after 6 months in it, I resigned once again due to toxic supervisor.  I was so depressed.  Sometimes I wish I just swallowed my ego, tried it out since the pay was so good without being in a leadership position and I loved the team I was in. I wish I had let go of titles and was willing to embrace a new experience.
Not committing to play tennis seriously when I had the opportunity.

For me it's a bit hard to say. For one hand I don't believe so much in the concept of regret. I like to think that every choice I made over the years are in a way responsible for who I'm today and I'm mostly proud of myself. So silly regrets like not learning a third language? Yes, but maybe "regret" is a strong word for that feeling. But in the end, wouldn't call it a regret itself but a wish. A wish to live life. I think although regret is a concept I don't fully "believe", is one that pushes me forward. The fear of regrets is more than a fuel than the regret itself. By the end I know I won't regret. I know that I'll do my best. As this idea, the need to avoid the regret, will keep me in line.
Having fear, playing safe and thus not making bolder choices

I regret that I was so angry at my mother for so many years.  She neglected me as a child - didn't touch me, didn't teach me how to deal with people.  We ate alone, fights were unsupervised.  I was lonely and unskilled in communication.  At 14 I wasn't allowed to attend my father's funeral or even to go home, and when I did return home he wasn't mentioned.  I wasn't taken to the dentist.  She avoided conflict.  I was angry with her from university until she was about 80.  Once I was an unhappy adult she kept trying to fix the relationship and I kept saying no to experiences she wanted to share, and I sometimes screamed at her.  I just found a letter to me that she wrote telling me how much she cried because I was so angry.  She was a very private person, and I caused her so much pain in not being willing to reconcile with her.  I regret that I didn't love her more fully and thank her for her efforts.

My biggest regret is saving my abusive (now ex) husband’s life. I prayed for years that he would be in a fatal single vehicle accident. What actually happened is he overdosed on prescription drugs (that I didn’t know he was addicted to) and I found him down. I stood over him for 2 minutes debating on whether or not to call 911, or if it was even necessary. Maybe he was just passed out drunk, again. After I saved his life he told me I was the source of all of his problems, how dare I embarrass him by calling 911. During the divorce he swore I would never be free of him and 8 years later his verbal, emotional, and psychological abuse continue, with the kids too. I later discovered he was also grooming our daughter. I have played it out in my head a thousand times. If I could go back in time I would pick the kids up from school and take them to a movie and dinner out and not be home until he was definitely dead.
I wish I had not been involved with my first husband at all.

When my oldest child came out to me as trans, I responded with shock and requests for information to help me understand.
